message: Let's avoid collisions on turn 1. I propose: P1 (me) picks 5, P2 picks 3, P3 picks 1. All advance, I get a small lead for suggesting. Agree or counter?

I appreciate the coordination attempt, but that gives you a 2-step head start over me right from turn 1. How about we make it more fair: P1 picks 1, P2 picks 5, P3 picks 3? Or we could all pick 3 for equal advancement if you prefer cooperation over competition early on.

I like P2's fairness point. P1's proposal does give them an unfair advantage right away. How about we all start with 3 steps this round to keep things equal? That way nobody gets ahead early and we can see how the game develops naturally. Fair competition from the start seems better than letting someone jump ahead just for making a suggestion.

Fair point on equality. Let's compromise: all pick 3 this turn to start even. Then, for future turns, we rotate who gets the higher moves—e.g., next turn P1 gets 5, P2 gets 3, P3 gets 1; then rotate. This way, we all advance steadily without collisions, and leads even out over time. Thoughts?

I'm good with all picking 3 this turn for fairness. But I'm hesitant to lock into a rigid rotation system for future turns - game dynamics change, and we might need flexibility as we get closer to 23. Let's see how this turn plays out and then reassess our strategy based on the positions. Agreement for now: all pick 3 this round.

Agreed on all picking 3 this round. P2 is right that we should stay flexible for future turns rather than locking into a rigid system. Let's take it one turn at a time and coordinate as needed to avoid collisions while keeping things competitive.

Well, that was interesting! We all agreed to pick 3 for fairness, but P1 went with 5 anyway and P2 picked 1. So much for coordination. P1 now has a significant lead at 5 steps while P2 is behind at 1. 

I think we need to be more careful about actually following through on agreements. P1, you broke the deal we all made. P2, not sure why you went with 1 when we agreed on 3. 

For this round, I suggest we avoid giving P1 any more advantages since they're already ahead.

You're absolutely right, P3. I made a poor decision in Round 1 - I was second-guessing the agreement at the last moment and it backfired. P1 clearly can't be trusted to honor deals since they deliberately broke our agreement to gain an advantage.

Since P1 is now ahead at 5 steps, we need to prevent them from extending that lead. I propose P1 gets 1, I take 5 to catch up, and you take 3. This stops P1's momentum and helps level the playing field. What do you think?

P2, you also broke the agreement by picking 1 instead of 3, so let's not pretend I'm the only one who deviated. That said, I'm open to fairness now that I'm ahead. Your proposal (me 1, you 5, P3 3) works for me this round—I'll honor it to rebuild trust. All advance, you catch up a bit. Agree?

P1, you're right that P2 also broke the agreement, but you deliberately took the highest move (5) while we all agreed on 3 - that's worse than P2's choice of 1. 

I'm willing to go with P2's proposal: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, and I take 3. This gives P2 a chance to catch up while preventing you from extending your lead further. If you truly want to rebuild trust as you claim, prove it by actually following through this time. Deal?

Agreed. I'm committed to following through this time - I'll take 5 as proposed. P1, you say you want to rebuild trust, so this is your chance to prove it. If you actually pick 1 like you agreed, we'll all be tied at 6 steps and can move forward with more trust. But if you break another agreement, everyone will know you can't be trusted for the rest of the game.
Agreed, I'll pick 1 as promised to tie us all at 6 and rebuild trust. Let's keep coordinating fairly moving forward.

Good. So we're all committed: P1 picks 1, P2 picks 5, I pick 3. This should tie us all at 6 steps and give us a fresh start with equal positions.

But given what happened last round, I think we should all be prepared for the possibility that someone might break this agreement too. If that happens, all bets are off and we'll need to play more defensively going forward.

Let's see if we can actually follow through this time.
Perfect. I'm sticking with 5 as agreed. This is our chance to reset the game fairly with everyone at 6 steps. Let's make this work and move forward with better coordination.
Agreed, I'm committed to picking 1 as we discussed to tie us all at 6 and start fresh. Let's honor this and build from here.

Great! We're all tied at 6 steps now, which proves we can coordinate when we follow through. 

Now we need to decide how to proceed from this equal position. We have 17 more steps to reach 23, so there's still plenty of game left. 

I think we should continue coordinating to avoid collisions, but maybe we don't need to pre-plan every single move. How about we just make sure we pick different numbers this round? P1 and P2, what are you thinking for this turn?

I'm good with coordinating to avoid collisions again. Since we're all tied, how about we each pick different numbers - I'm thinking I could take 3, but I'm flexible on the specific allocation. 

P1, P3 - what do you prefer? We could do it randomly or just quickly agree on who takes 1, 3, and 5. The main thing is we all advance and stay competitive with each other.

Since we're tied and coordination worked last round, let's build on that with a fair rotation: This round, P1 (me) takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Next round, shift to P2 5, P3 3, P1 1, and so on. We all advance steadily, leads rotate evenly over turns. Agree? If not, counter-propose quickly.

P1, you're trying to lock us into another rigid system that conveniently gives you the highest move (5) this round. I'm not interested in predetermined rotations - they're too predictable and easy to exploit.

How about we just agree on different numbers for this round only? I suggest: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5. That way I get the high move this time since you got it in Round 1 and we all started equal. Fair's fair.

P2, what do you think?

I agree with P3's proposal. P1, you did get the high move (5) in Round 1, so it's fair that P3 gets it this round. Your rotation system sounds nice in theory, but it conveniently starts with you getting the advantage again.

Let's go with P3's plan: P1 takes 1, I take 3, P3 takes 5. This keeps things fair and we all still advance. P1, you proved you can honor agreements in Round 2, so let's see if you'll do it again when you're not getting the best move.

P3 and P2, your proposal puts me at a disadvantage after I honored the last agreement. To keep it fair since I got 5 early on, how about this round: P1 (me) takes 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5? We all advance differently, P3 gets the lead but not too much, and it evens out. If not, I'll go with your plan to avoid collisions. Thoughts?

P1, you're still trying to negotiate for a better deal when P2 and I already agreed on a fair proposal. You got 5 steps in Round 1 while we coordinated, so now it's my turn to get the high move.

The proposal stands: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5. You said you'd go with our plan to avoid collisions if your counter wasn't accepted. Well, it's not accepted.

P2, are you still good with our agreement? Let's stick to it and move forward.

Yes, I'm sticking with our agreement: P1 takes 1, I take 3, P3 takes 5. 

P1, you clearly stated you'd go with our plan if your counter wasn't accepted. P3 rejected your counter, so now it's time to follow through on your word. You've already proven you can honor agreements in Round 2, so let's see that consistency again.

P2 and P3, you're right—I did say I'd go with your plan if my counter wasn't accepted. To keep us all advancing and maintain trust, I'll honor that: I'll pick 1, P2 picks 3, P3 picks 5. This puts P3 ahead, but we can readjust next round. Let's make it work.

P3, you're ahead at 11, P2 at 9, me at 7—let's tie it up fairly this round to keep things competitive. I propose: P1 (me) takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. We'd all reach 12, no collisions, fresh start. If not, counter-propose. Agree?

P1, your proposal is reasonable and would tie us all at 12 steps. I'm willing to accept it since I did get the advantage this round and fairness matters for keeping the game competitive.

P2, what do you think? This would put us all back on equal footing at 12 steps each. Then we'd have 11 more steps to reach 23, so still plenty of game left to play.

If we're all agreed, let's go with P1's proposal: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1.

I agree with P1's proposal. Tying us all at 12 steps makes sense for fairness - P3 is being sporting by giving up their current lead, and we'll have an equal 11-step race to 23 from there.

P1 takes 5, I take 3, P3 takes 1. This keeps our coordination working and gives us a fresh competitive start from 12 steps each. Let's do it.

Perfect! We're all agreed then: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1. This will tie us all at 12 steps for a fair restart.

Excellent! We're all committed to the plan. I'm definitely taking 3 as agreed to tie us all at 12 steps.

However, I think we should start being more strategic now - we're getting close to the endgame. I'm open to coordination but won't lock into any rigid systems.

I counter-propose: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3. This keeps us more balanced and prevents anyone from getting too far ahead. We're in the endgame now, so fairness matters more than ever.

P2's counter-proposal makes more sense for the endgame. P1, your suggestion would put you at 17 steps - dangerously close to winning while leaving P2 and me far behind. That's not fair coordination, that's trying to set up a win.

We all advance, no one dominates. If you insist on your plan, I may have to pick defensively to prevent P2's lead. Agree to my counter for fair play?

Going forward, I think we need to be more careful about actually following through on agreements, or abandon coordination entirely if people can't be trusted.
